meta.title: Step Count Accuracy by Wearable Device â€” Tool Data
meta.description: Consolidated research data for building a step count accuracy comparison tool on kygo.app
meta.source_notes: All data sourced from peer-reviewed studies unless marked. 'WellnessPulse (2025)' and 'AIM7 (2025)' are consumer-facing data aggregations, not peer-reviewed journals â€” treat as supplementary.

devices.name: Garmin
devices.bias_detail: Consistently undercounts on treadmill at most speeds. Significant undercounting at very slow speeds (<1.6 km/h). May overcount during incline walking.
devices.algorithm_type: Threshold-based peak detection with 10-step minimum bout filter
devices.key_differentiator: 10-step minimum bout threshold: watch does not register steps until 10+ consecutive step-like patterns detected, then retroactively credits all 10. Dramatically reduces phantom steps but misses very short walking bursts (<10 steps).
devices.weaknesses: Undercounts at very slow speeds; can count driving vibrations; entry-level models lack gyroscope

devices.name: Apple Watch
devices.sensors: 3-axis accelerometer, 3-axis gyroscope, always-on motion coprocessor, GPS
devices.bias_detail: Slight overestimate at slow speeds, slight underestimate at jogging pace. Near-perfect overall (0.034% total error across all speeds in one study).
devices.algorithm_type: ML-enhanced peak detection via Core Motion framework
devices.key_differentiator: High dynamic range gyroscope (Ultra); GPS-calibrated stride length over time; arm-swing pattern recognition with rotation data; always-on motion coprocessor offloads CPU for 24/7 tracking.
devices.best_for: All-around step tracking with highest consistency across speeds and activity types
devices.weaknesses: Higher error at slow walking (23.9% MAPE for light-intensity); some phantom steps while driving
devices.notable_finding: Apple Watch Series 6 achieved r=0.99 correlation against ActivPAL reference in a 24-hour free-living study â€” the highest independent correlation among consumer wearables tested.

devices.name: Fitbit
devices.bias_direction: Mixed (underestimates in lab, overestimates in free-living)
devices.bias_detail: Notable pattern: underestimates in lab conditions, overestimates in free-living. Meets acceptable accuracy approximately half the time. Within-brand variation: Fitbit Classic overestimates, Fitbit Charge underestimates.
devices.algorithm_type: MEMS tri-axial peak detection + ML model (evolving post-Google acquisition)
devices.key_differentiator: Most-validated brand with 144 studies across 12 models. Ankle placement dramatically improves accuracy: 5.9% error at 0.4 m/s vs. 48â€“75% error waist-worn.
devices.best_for: General fitness tracking; most validation research available
devices.weaknesses: Higher free-living error than Garmin/Apple; within-brand inconsistency between models

devices.name: Samsung Galaxy Watch
devices.overall_accuracy_note: Moderate (r=0.82 vs ActivPAL â€” lower than Apple Watch's r=0.99 in same study)
devices.bias_detail: User reports of 2,000â€“3,500+ phantom steps per day during desk work, driving, and stationary bike workouts. Gyroscope may be overly sensitive to non-walking arm movements.
devices.key_differentiator: BioActive Sensor integrates multiple sensors. Samsung Health can fuse phone + watch step data (may introduce discrepancies).
devices.weaknesses: Fewer validation studies; user-reported phantom steps; weaker correlation than Apple Watch

devices.name: COROS
devices.overall_accuracy_note: Good (~98.6% in walking test; near-exact for running)
devices.bias_detail: Requires continuous arm movement to trigger counting; filters out brief stops.
devices.algorithm_type: Peak detection with continuous-motion filter + barometric altimeter
devices.key_differentiator: Requires continuous arm movement to trigger counting. Excellent running step accuracy. Long battery life.
devices.weaknesses: No peer-reviewed validation; filters out short walking bursts; requires continuous motion to count

devices.name: Polar
devices.rank_label: Moderate to Poor â€” Not a Step Counter
devices.overall_accuracy_note: Moderate to poor (53.2% in meta-analysis); overreports ~3.8%
devices.bias_detail: Both peer-reviewed studies and consumer tests show Polar adds extra steps. High sensitivity to wrist movements with less aggressive false-positive filtering.
devices.algorithm_type: Proprietary peak detection on wrist accelerometer
devices.key_differentiator: Best known for heart rate monitoring (chest strap heritage), not step counting. Step tracking is secondary to HR/training load focus.
devices.best_for: Heart rate monitoring, training load â€” NOT step counting
devices.weaknesses: A360 found not valid for any walking condition; Vantage overreports; cannot replace research-grade accelerometers

devices.name: Oura Ring
devices.rank_label: Poor for Steps â€” Excellent for Sleep/HRV
devices.sensors: 3-axis accelerometer, infrared PPG, skin temperature sensor
devices.overall_accuracy_note: Poor (50.3% error real-world aggregate); acceptable in controlled walking (<10% MAPE)
devices.bias_detail: Acceptable lab accuracy but +2,124 Â± 4,256 steps overestimate in free-living (14-day study). Phantom steps from hand activity are the primary issue.
devices.algorithm_type: ML step classifier on finger-worn accelerometer data
devices.key_differentiator: Finger placement detects hand motion as proxy for steps. Surprisingly good in controlled walking (within 12 steps of 5,000). Terrible in real-world conditions due to hand gestures.
false_step_triggers: Any repetitive hand motion mimicking walking cadence
devices.best_for: Sleep, HRV, recovery â€” NOT step counting
devices.weaknesses: Phantom steps from hand movement (thousands per day); finger placement fundamentally limited for steps
devices.oura_recommendation: Use Oura for health trends, not step-count parity with wrist devices

devices.name: WHOOP
devices.overall_accuracy_note: Unknown â€” no published validation studies
devices.bias_detail: Step counting only added October 2024 via firmware update. Hardware should theoretically enable good accuracy but no studies exist.
devices.algorithm_type: Accelerometer cadence + gyroscope rotational data (new algorithm, Oct 2024)
devices.key_differentiator: WHOOP intentionally positions Strain (cardiovascular load) as primary metric, with steps as supplementary. Newest step tracker on this list.
devices.best_for: Strain/recovery tracking â€” step counting is new and unvalidated
devices.weaknesses: Feature launched Oct 2024; no peer-reviewed studies; WHOOP deprioritizes steps vs. Strain

accuracy_factors.description: Factors that affect step count accuracy across all devices, ranked by impact

factors.detail: Accuracy drops dramatically below 0.9 m/s. At very slow speeds, even best devices miss majority of steps.

data.note: All devices struggle; ankle placement helps

factors.detail: Wrist devices detect arm swing as proxy for walking, not actual footfalls. This fundamental limitation creates systematic errors.

data.limitation: Less convenient; users forget to wear

factors.key_finding: Difference between wrist and hip step counts: 30% in young adults, nearly 50% in elderly

factors.detail: Restricted arm swing causes undercounting; exaggerated swing causes overcounting.
Apple Watch MAPE: 4.3% for age <40 vs. 10.9% for age â‰¥40. Age affects gait pattern, walking speed, and arm swing â€” all of which compound to reduce accuracy.
Lab/controlled settings consistently show better accuracy than free-living. All devices perform ~5% MAPE in lab vs. >10% in real-world.
Algorithms trained on healthy gait detect only 11â€“47% of steps in individuals with neurological conditions (stroke, Parkinson's, etc.). Population-specific algorithms are essential.
factors.source: Sensors (2025), DOI not yet available; Lamont et al. (2018)

factors.detail: BMI itself does not directly impact step count device accuracy per Modave et al. (2017). However, obesity alters gait patterns (slower speed, shorter steps, wider stance, reduced arm swing) which indirectly reduces accuracy through the walking speed and arm swing factors.
factors.source: Modave et al. (2017), JMIR; Scataglini et al. (2025), Int J Obes

factors.detail: Loose band = more noise = more false positives. A snug (not tight) fit reduces signal noise.
Garmin validated across natural lawn, gravel, asphalt, linoleum, ceramic tile with acceptable MAPE on all surfaces.
Garmin shown to overcount during incline walking. Changes in stride mechanics on hills can affect detection.
Treadmill walking produces different arm-swing patterns than overground walking, leading to different accuracy profiles.
Modave et al. (2017) found dominant hand does not significantly impact step count accuracy.

by_condition.most_affected: All devices at slow gait speeds

accuracy_metrics_explained.description: How step count accuracy is measured in research, ranked by informativeness

metrics.name: MAPE (Mean Absolute Percentage Error)
metrics.what_it_measures: Average of absolute % differences; prevents positive/negative errors canceling out

metrics.name: MPE (Mean Percentage Error)
metrics.what_it_measures: Average % difference; can mask errors if over/underestimates cancel
metrics.why_it_matters: Shows direction of bias but can appear falsely good

metrics.name: Mean Difference (Bias)
metrics.what_it_measures: Average raw difference in step count
metrics.why_it_matters: Simple but doesn't scale with step volume

metrics.name: Bland-Altman Mean Bias
metrics.what_it_measures: Systematic over/underestimation with 95% limits of agreement

metrics.name: Correlation (r or ICC)
metrics.why_it_matters: High r doesn't mean accurate â€” a device consistently off by 2,000 steps can still have r=0.99

accuracy_metrics_explained.example: A device that overestimates by 500 steps half the time and underestimates by 500 steps the other half shows 0% MPE (appearing perfect) but 10%+ MAPE (revealing true error).

how_step_counting_works.description: Technical pipeline all consumer wearables use

steps.name: Raw Signal Acquisition
steps.detail: 3-axis MEMS accelerometer captures acceleration in x, y, z at 25â€“100 Hz sampling rate

steps.name: Signal Preprocessing
steps.detail: Compute vector magnitude âˆš(xÂ² + yÂ² + zÂ²) to combine all axes into single value

steps.name: Noise Filtering
steps.detail: Low-pass filter (cutoff ~3â€“10 Hz) removes high-frequency noise; band-pass filter (0.5â€“3 Hz) isolates walking cadence range

steps.name: Step Detection
steps.detail: Peak detection, zero-crossing, or autocorrelation identifies periodic patterns matching walking

steps.name: Validation Gate
steps.detail: Time-window constraints (0.2sâ€“2.0s between steps) filter false positives; minimum-bout thresholds (e.g., 10+ consecutive steps) reduce phantom counts

steps.name: Post-Processing
steps.detail: Machine learning classifiers distinguish walking from non-walking activities

algorithm_categories.name: ML-Enhanced Detection
algorithm_categories.note: Classifies walking vs non-walking first, then applies peak detection

algorithm_categories.name: Deep Learning (End-to-End)
algorithm_categories.note: Neural networks trained directly on accelerometer data

algorithm_categories.name: Autocorrelation Analysis
algorithm_categories.note: Identifies periodic patterns; more computationally intensive

how_step_counting_works.fundamental_limitation: Wrist-worn devices detect arm swing as a proxy for walking â€” not actual footfalls. This creates systematic errors no algorithm can fully eliminate.
how_step_counting_works.gold_standard: Manual hand-tally counting (controlled) or research-grade hip-worn accelerometers (ActiGraph, ActivPAL) for free-living

important_caveats: Lab â‰  Real World. All devices: ~5% MAPE in lab vs. >10% in free-living.
Walking speed is the #1 confounder. Below 0.9 m/s, expect large undercounts.
Wrist placement measures arm motion, not footfalls. Push a cart = undercounting. Wave arms = overcounting.
Oura Ring is NOT a step counter despite showing acceptable lab accuracy.
WHOOP has zero validation data for steps (feature added Oct 2024).
Garmin's 10-step gate trades sensitivity for specificity â€” misses very short walking bursts.
Most validation studies used older device models. Current-gen may perform better but is unconfirmed.
Only ~11% of consumer wearables have been validated for any biometric. 249 studies = 3.5% of what's needed.
Check if device manufacturers funded the study. Independent studies sometimes differ.
For clinical/research use, hip-worn research-grade accelerometers (ActiGraph, ActivPAL) remain the standard.
Steps are algorithmic estimates, not direct footfall counts.
Individual variation is significant: gait, arm swing, BMI, age, speed all affect accuracy. Published MAPE values are population averages.
